WRITING.TEXT: I identify with this so much. When there is too much food in the house I get incredibly anxious to the point that I sometimes start throwing stuff out. Which makes me feel wasteful which makes me worry when there is too much food. It's an awful cycle.
Any class taught by him is great. I enjoyed his Serbian lit class. I want to say it was 400 something but I can't remember.
Huge congrats for choosing to embark down the road to recovery. I know you can do it. Look how far you have already come! :)

Hey, I don't have any advice for you but I just wanted to respond and let you know that you aren't alone. I have the same problem right now. My therapist suggests trying to pin point why you need to overcompensate. Like what purpose it serves you now. It served a purpose at one time when you were actively restricting but now it isn't useful. Easier said than done though. Stay strong! :)
It scares me how relatable this is. Amazing job.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone have a copy of "A house divided" by Jodom Productions?
WRITING.TEXT: It turns out that this low budged indie film was taped at the house my uncle bought recently. My family has been struggling to find a copy. Does anyone know where I could find it? Also, sorry if this is the wrong subreddit!

Physically, it gets better, it really does even though it's hard to see when you are in pain. Like the other poster said, small frequent meals helps while your stomach expands. Also, it's important to keep with it and push through the pain because the only way out is through unfortunately. You can do this!

Thank you so much for the encouragement! I was able to get in with my therapist which is slowly pulling me out of this rut. It's still a tough time for whatever reason but at least I'm moving in the right direction now- even if very slowly.
I wish haha. It's not legal where I am, and my parents wouldn't support that. I had to move back in with them for a little bit while I get my life stabilized.

I haven't done journaling for ED but I did through most of my adolescence just for normal angsty stuff and it seemed to help so maybe I will have to start it up for ED. Anyway, thank you so much for the encouragement and support. It's very much appreciated as I've been having a very rough week and a half.

Thanks for the welcome and encouragement! I've been lurking for a while, and I have to say that I really like the community here. I am very much plagued by black and white thinking and it's hard for me to remember that recovery is a process and a bad day or two doesn't mean I should just toss in the towel and go back to full anorexia mode.
That's a really good idea. I am going to give the clinic a call as soon as they open. Thanks for the response and support. It really means a lot.

WRITING.TITLE: How do I stop this relapse?
WRITING.TEXT: Short version of my story is that I am about 2 months into my formal recovery from anorexia (working with a therapist and living at home with my parents). I was doing so well. I mean don't get me wrong, eating more has been hard as hell but I was making progress and am nearing half way to my restored weight. Last Monday, after my appointment, though, something just snapped in my brain and I had uncontrollable urges to restrict and over exercise. I have been indulging in these for a week, and I'm starting to get back to that dark place where all I can think of is food and I beat myself up over a few extra calories. Does anyone have any advice on how to break this mini relapse and get back to gaining instead of losing?
Letters and sciences. Did you list a different (non-wiscmail) email address as your primary contact address?

Thanks! I actually just got an email a few minutes ago saying that diplomas have been shipped and should be arriving pretty soon.

I opened up student center to check for grades this morning and on the front page thing it said "you are not enrolled in any classes". Strangest moment ever.
And now Gordon rushes for 500 yards.
Yeah, and this has probably lead to more Ebola infections because people are lumped together in treatment centers when it turns out that their primary issue was one of the diseases you mentioned.
Great list! I would also add to this that many people in WA are suffering from another health issue which makes them more succeptible. Malnutrition, malaria, and possibly HIV come to mind.

News coming out of this part od the world should be taken with a grain of salt so you do have a point. However, it is entirely possible for a virus to decline naturally.
If there aren't enough succeptible hosts left, infection rates will drop. This doesn't mean that there aren't still large populations which could be sickened; it just means there aren't enough spacially and temporally located to allow for the exponential growth we were previously seeing. The 1918 flu eventually burnt itself out. It was a much larger scale and a different virus, but the concepts are the same.
That being said, we won't know for sure for a few more months as other posters have said.
It must be nice to live in a country that accepts science.

I think BSL-4 labs. My profesor has a friend who works in one and was saying that the Ebola hysteria has made it so that samples of Ebola (and other samples that were stored near Ebola) aren't being transferred. The transport companies are refusing to transport.
There really isn't much money going in period, but I think what is has been allocated for building more isolation facilities.

You must have misinterpreted my stance and the line of conversation. I am defending HCW's here. Another person was saying how whiney and entitled they are acting and I was making the point that, like military members, they are not whiney and complaining- they are important heros who deserve respect. I agree that they should be paid. I think the way they are being demonized during this Ebola stuff is horrible and absurd.

This is true with every blood donation though. There is a slight risk of getting HIV from a blood donation if someone lies about the fact they might have contracted it. There is a period where it won't show up in blood tests.

WRITING.TITLE: Mice infected with a mouse adapted strain of Ebola develop a wide range of disease phenotypes

WRITING.TEXT: In interpersonal relationships, I'm all for compassion and being considerate with what you do and say, but not in public policy.
Oh there are some panicking; have you read some of the fear driven ridiculousness discussed on here?

Right. The reaction by officials is over the top, but they guy probably still should have known better. Same with the guy on the flight to the Caribbean who was removed by the hazmat team. The climate around ebolaphobia is ridiculous.
I mean the reaction by the officials was unsurprisingly over the top, but this man is an idiot if he thought everyone would giggle and he wouldn't get in trouble.
We know this law has no basis in science but we will defend it anyway because the general masses are irrationally worried. Imagine if we made all of our decisions like that in this country.
HCW's have been returning to the US from Ebola outbreaks for years and literally no one cared until now. Panic.
Who is trying to spread Ebola? Conspiratorial nonsense.
I fear for the lives of some of these poor HCW's. I don't trust that some derranged, fear-riddled person won't attack them in the streets. Even months post disease/ media covered return to the US.

Not just returning from this outbreak, but from previous outbreaks of both Ebola and other regionally endemic diseases. And no one cared. Most of these Ebola hysteria people probably aren't even aware that Eboa has existed for more than 3 months.
I'm not symptomatic of small pox yet.

I don't think this point is really being made by anyone. No one is saying that the quarentine is a bad idea because Ebola will get in anyway. People, including myself, are arguing that the quarentine is harmful in that it reduces the pool of potential volunteers in Africa. This has not an 'oh, well, it's gonna happen anyway so fuck it' type situation. The bottom line is that there is no scientific basis for quarentining asymptotic HCW's.

That figure also doesn't include mild cases where the profuse symptoms aren't present. From what I've read, some people will mount an immune response and fend off the virus with few if any symptoms. These people are not infectious since their bodies don't allow for a large viral load to ever occur. More research needs to be done to confirm this, but it proven true, it would significantly drop that mortality rate statistic.
Gotcha. Thanks for the correction!

It has not been spread to any urban areas in the US. This is a gross exaggeration. Yes, we are still in the 21 day period for Spencer, but barring 20 sudden infections, you cannoy make that statement.
It is reassuring to see the international community focusing on the epicenter of the epidemic.

Another thread on here referenced the fact that the r0 for Ebola (in Liberia) drops below 1 when traditional burial practices don't take place. If we reach the end of the incubation period with no new infections in Mali, I think that will really help demonstrate this fact to people. It probably won't change the burial culture, but we can hope. At the very least, it will hopefully help to mitigate unfounded panic about secondary transmission in other parts of the world.
True.
Damn those civil liberties.
China did not lie about H5N1 nor H7N9. There are many examples of countries not lying as well.
Americans have an unfortunate habit of reacting irrationally to fear and surrendering liberty in exchange for what they think is protection. Patriot Act, anyone?

He's also voluntarily quarantining himself which is an important thing to remember. In making this decision, he has probably weighed personal factors which contribute to him thinking it's relevant for him.
